content: I won’t comment on ‘happiness’ or ‘success’ or ‘purpose’ because those are mostly relative concepts tied to individual experience. Popular culture seems quite confused about what those things even mean in terms of socioeconomic realities. Don’t take my word for it, though: Spend time in Topeka, Detroit or East Camden and you can see for yourself. I will say this: it’s one thing to learn about yourself in your world, and a whole other thing to learn about yourself in relation to others from many different worlds. I say this because it’s convenient for any one of us who has the access to make abnormal amounts of money or who can lead a somewhat privileged life to say things like “money doesn’t matter” or that “happiness is something else” etcetera. Convenience doesn’t change what is dysfunctional or indiscernible about the world we collectively experience. Discomfort, uncertainty and a general acceptance of emerging possibility do change things, often for the better — and perhaps this is what the author means by adaptivity. Alas, my business partner, Andrew Markell, explains the central point much better than I do. So, You Want Disruptive Change(In 2014 I was asked to give a TED X talk in Sacramento California. I have never been a fan of TED, and was hesitant to…medium.com My favorite quote/excerpt: One must be estranged to see clearly — one must be outside something to get to the bottom of it. And our job is to get to the bottom of what is going on all around us so that we can activate change that means something. Perhaps some of this will resonate with the author and some commentors. Cheers.
